Article.ArticleTitle: Pollution characteristics, sources, and photochemical roles of ambient carbonyl compounds in summer of Beijing, China.

AbstractText: Ambient carbonyls are important precursors of radicals and ground-level ozone (O<sub>3</sub>). In this study, sources, precursors, and impacts on radicals and O<sub>3</sub> of carbonyls were investigated based on online observations of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) at an urban site in Beijing during June 2021. Carbonyls accounted for 36% and 42% of mixing ratios and OH reactivity for total measured VOCs, respectively. Formaldehyde was the most abundant carbonyl, with the mean level of 4.13 ± 2.28 ppb. Source apportionment results based on the multi linear regression (MLR) method suggested that secondary production contributed 41%, 25%, 36%, and 30% of formaldehyde, acetaldehyde, propanal, and acetone, respectively. Key precursors of carbonyls were then identified based on the calculation of their production rates. It was found that alkenes contributed 59%-80% of aldehydes production. Impacts of carbonyls on HO<sub>x</sub> radicals (OH and HO<sub>2</sub>) and O<sub>3</sub> production were explored using a box model based on observations (OBM). Photolysis of HONO, formaldehyde, and O<sub>3</sub> were the dominant primary sources of HO<sub>x</sub> radicals during daytime of O<sub>3</sub> pollution days, with average relative contributions of 52%, 28%, and 19% to the total primary production rate of HO<sub>x</sub>, respectively. Aldehydes accounted for 32% (20% from formaldehyde) of average HO<sub>x</sub> removal rates. The relative incremental reactivity (RIR) values of NO<sub>x</sub> determined by the OBM were negative, suggesting that the O<sub>3</sub>-VOCs-NO<sub>x</sub> sensitivity was in the VOCs-limited regime. Using the observed concentrations of carbonyls as constraints of OBM, the absolute values of RIR for NO<sub>x</sub> tended to increase but those for anthropogenic VOCs tended to decrease. Formaldehyde showed the largest RIR value for anthropogenic VOCs during O<sub>3</sub> pollution days. These findings indicated the important impacts of carbonyls on O<sub>3</sub> production and O<sub>3</sub>-VOCs-NO<sub>x</sub> sensitivity.
